title: Collapse the "missing lifetime specifier" error when there are multiple errors within a single item

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org -->

```rust
struct Shape {
    name: &str,
    color: &str,
}

fn main() {
    let shape = Shape { name: "pentagon", color: "blue" };
    assert!(shape.name, "pentagon");
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0106]: missing lifetime specifier
 --> src/main.rs:2:11
  |
2 |     name: &str,
  |           ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
help: consider introducing a named lifetime parameter
  |
1 ~ struct Shape<'a> {
2 ~     name: &'a str,
  |

error[E0106]: missing lifetime specifier
 --> src/main.rs:3:12
  |
3 |     color: &str,
  |            ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
help: consider introducing a named lifetime parameter
  |
1 ~ struct Shape<'a> {
2 |     name: &str,
3 ~     color: &'a str,
  |

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0106`.
```

Ideally the output should look like:

```
error[E0106]: missing lifetime specifiers
 --> src/main.rs:2:11
  |
2 |     name: &str,
  |           ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
3 |     color: &str,
  |            ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
help: consider introducing named lifetime parameters
  |
1 ~ struct Shape<'a> {
2 ~     name: &'a str,
3 ~     color: &'a str,
  |

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0106`.
```

Filing at the request of @estebank, after I made this mistake in a real project. [Brief discussion thread on Twitter](https://twitter.com/alexwlchan/status/1464508309688528904).
